item.title: Plasmodium falciparum: Habits and Habitat, Structure, Reproduction, Life-cycle, and Economic Importance
item.description:
Plasmodium falciparum: Habits and Habitat, Structure, Reproduction, Life-cycle, and Economic Importance

Plasmodium falciparum is a single-celled protozoan parasite that causes the deadliest form of malaria in humans. It belongs to the genus Plasmodium and spreads mainly through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. Malaria caused by P. falciparum is widespread in tropical and subtropical regions, and it remains one of the leading causes of death in many developing countries.
